sections.title: Abstract\t
paragraphs: Subjectivity\banalysis\band\bauthorship\battribution\bare\bvery\bpopular\bareas\bof\bresearch.\bHowever,\bwork\bin\bthese\btwo\bareas\bhas\bbeen\bdone\b separately.\bOur\bconjecture\bis\bthat\bby\bcombining\binformation\babout\bsubjectivity\bin\btexts\band\bauthorship,\bthe\bperformance\bof\bboth\btasks\b can\bbe\bimproved.\bIn\bthe\bpaper\ba\bpersonalized\bapproach\bto\bopinion\bmining\bis\bpresented,\bin\bwhich\b the\bnotions\bof\bpersonal\bsense\band\b idiolect\b are\b introduced;\b the\b approach\b is\b applied\b to\b the\b polarity\b classification\b task.\b It\b is\b assumed\b that\b different\b authors\b express\b their\b private\bstates\bin\btext\bindividually,\band\bopinion\bmining\bresults\bcould\bbe\bimproved\bby\banalyzing\btexts\bby\bdifferent\bauthors\bseparately.\bThe\b hypothesis\bis\btested\bon\ba\bcorpus\bof\bmovie\breviews\bby\bten\bauthors.\bThe\bresults\bof\bapplying\bthe\bpersonalized\bapproach\bto\bopinion\bmining\b are\bpresented,\bconfirming\bthat\bthe\bapproach\bincreases\bthe\bperformance\bof\bthe\bopinion\bmining\btask.\bAutomatic\bauthorship\battribution\bis\b further\b applied\b to\b model\b the\b personalized\b approach,\b classifying\b documents\b by\b their\b assumed\b authorship.\b Although\b the\b automatic\b authorship\b classification\b imposes\b a\b number\b of\b limitations\b on\b the\b dataset\b for\b further\b experiments,\b after\b overcoming\b these\b issues\b the\b authorship\b attribution\b technique\b modeling\b the\b personalized\b approach\b confirms\b the\b increase\b over\b the\b baseline\b with\b no\b authorship\b information\bused.\b

sections.title: \t 1. \fntroduction\t
paragraphs: \fesearch\b on\b analysis\b of\b blogpost\b writings\b is\b an\b area\b attracting\ban\bincreasing\bamount\bof\battention.\bOn\bone\bhand,\b one\b of\b the\b popular\b research\b domains\b is\b the\b analysis\b of\b documents\b containing\b the\b subjective\b opinion\b of\b the\b author.\b\tuch\bwork\bis\bdedicated\bto\bthe\bsubject\bof\beliciting\b the\b emotions\b and\b opinions\b of\b the\b author.\b A\b well-known\b task\bin\bsubjectivity\banalysis\bis\bthe\bpolarity\bclassification\bof\b documents:\b texts\b that\b contain\b product\b reviews\b for\b example,\b can\b be\b divided\b into\b two\b groups:\b positive\b and\b negative\breviews.\bA\bbroad\bdescription\bof\bthe\bwork\bdone\bin\b the\b area\b of\b subjectivity\b analysis,\b and\b namely,\b polarity\b classification,\bcan\bbe\bfound\bin\b(Pang,\b2008).\bOn\bthe\bother\b hand,\b another\b research\b subject\b attracting\b considerable\b interest\b is\b the\b discovery\b of\b the\b identity\b or\b characteristics\b of\b an\b individual,\b based\b on\b their\b writings.\b Not\b only\b objective\b characteristics\b of\b a\b writer,\b like\b personal\b traits,\b age\b or\b gender,\b can\b be\b successfully\b detected\b (Schler,\b 2006),\b but\b the\b actual\b author\b of\b documents\b can\b also\bbe\b identified,\b and\b cases\b of\b plagiarism\b resolved\b (Koppel,\b 2008).\b\b \b Work\b in\b these\b two\b areas,\b subjectivity\b analysis\b and\b authorship\b attribution,\b has\b hitherto\b been\b carried\b out\b independently\b of\b the\b other.\b However\b we\b believe\b that\b not\b only\bhave\bthese\bareas\ba\blot\bto\bcontribute\bto\beach\bother,\bbut\b also\b that\b research\b on\b authorship\b attribution\b and\b subjectivity\b analysis\b should\b be\b done\b in\b a\b joint\b way.\b The\b reason\b for\b this\b is\b that\b our\b personality\b traits,\b occupation,\b age\band\bgender\bare\bvery\bclosely\binterrelated\bwith\bwhat\bwe\b think,\b feel\b and\b express,\b ie.,\b our\b ‘private\b states’\b(Pang,\b 2008).\b \b In\b this\b paper,\b we\b present\b our\b experiments\b designed\b to\b test\bour\bhypothesis\bthat\bappraisal\bpolarity\bis\bexpressed\bin\b an\b individual\b way\b by\b different\b authors,\b and\b that\b by\b harnessing\b knowledge\b of\b the\b writer's\b idiolect\b we\b can\b improve\bthe\bresults\bof\bthe\bpolarity\bclassification\btask.\bWe\b expect\b authorship\b information\b to\b be\b useful\b for\b sentiment\b analysis.\bHowever,\bsuch\binformation\bis\bnot\balways\beasily\b found\b in\b the\b World\b Wide\b Web.\b We\b describe\b a\b methodology\b to\b combine\b information\b about\b the\b author’s\b personality\b with\b that\b of\b their\b private\b states,\b and\bdiscuss\b limitations.\b

sections.title: 2. Persona\b\tSense\tand\t\fdio\bect\t
paragraphs: \b We\bbelieve\bthat\binformation\bon\bauthorship\band\bauthor’s\b personality\bcan\bbe\bsuccessfully\butilised\bin\bthe\bsubjectivity\b analysis.\b Information\b about\b an\b author’s\b private\b states\b –\b her/his\bfeelings,\blikes\band\bdislikes\b–\bcan\breveal\baspects\bof\b their\b personality\b characteristics.\b All\b of\b these\b form\b a\b person’s\b idiolect\b –\b ‘a\b language\b that\b can\b be\b characterized\b exhaustively\b in\b terms\b of\b ...\b properties\b of\b some\b single\b person\b at\b a\b time’\b (Barber,\b 2009).\b An\b idiolect\b would\b represent\b a\b collection\b of\b personal\b characteristics\bat\b the\b same\b time,\b ie.,\b age,\b gender,\b social\b class,\b occupation,\b as\b well\b as\b personal\b traits\b and\b private\b states.\b Thus,\b idiolect\b can\b be\b seen\b as\b a\b combination\b of\b the\b so-called\b sociolect,\b genderlect,\bslang,\bjargon,\betc.\b \b Words\b have\b word-meaning\b that\b is\b common\b in\b the\b language\b and\b that\b is\b represented\b in\b their\b usage.\b We\b believe\b that\b another\b component\b of\b word-meaning\b –\b “personal\bsense”\b(Leontev,\b1978)\b–\bthat\bis\bnot\binherent\bin\b the\b language,\b but\b is\b different\b for\b each\b person,\b can\b carry\b personal\b information\b and\b combine\b the\b tasks.\b This\b component\b reflects\b a\b meaning\b of\b the\b word\b in\b terms\b of\b unique\b experience\b of\b a\b person,\b reflecting\b partly\b their\b private\b states,\b and\b partly\b their\b unique\b personal\b characteristics.\b\b \b Word-meaning\b and\b personal\b sense\b are\b manifested\b implicitly\bin\bspeech.\bOur\bhypothesis\bis\bthat\bpersonal\bsense\b

will\b influence\b language\b use\b of\b an\b author,\b forming\b an\b idiolect.\bThe\bgoal\bof\bour\bwork\bhere\bis\bto\bmake\buse\bof\bthese\b individual\b idiolects\b in\b order\b to\b facilitate\b sentiment\b analysis,\bpersonality\band\bauthorship\battribution\btasks.\b

sections.title: 3. Experiment:\tthe\tPersona\bized\t Approach\tto\tOpinion\tMining\t\t 3.1\t Knowing\tthe\tAuthor\t
paragraphs: In\b opinion\b mining\b and\b polarity\b classification\b tasks\b the\b goal\bis\busually\bto\battach\ba\bdocument,\bor\ba\bpiece\bof\btext,\bto\b one\bclass\bor\banother.\bIn\bpolarity\bclassification,\bdocuments\b are\b classified\b as\b having\b positive\b or\b negative\b opinion\b towards\b a\b product.\b From\b a\b formal\b point\b of\b view\b there\b should\b be\b a\b big\b difference\b between\b the\b documents\b expressing\bpositive\band\bnegative\bopinion\bpolarity,\bin\border\b for\b the\b classification\b to\b be\b possible.\b Strong\b results\b in\b opinion\b analysis\b confirm\b this\b to\b be\b the\b case,\b see\b for\b example,\b(Pang,\b2008).\b \b However,\b the\b authorship\b of\b the\b documents\b is\b not\b normally\btaken\binto\baccount.\bGiven\btwo\bsets\bof\bdocuments\b by\b Author1\b (A1)\b and\b Author2\b (A2),\b we\b find\b some\b features\bthat\bA1\band\bA2\bwill\bhave\bin\bcommon\bin\bpositive\b appraisal\bdocuments,\band\bother\bfeatures\bthat\bwill\bwork\bfor\b both\b A1\b and\b A2\b in\b negative\b appraisal\b documents.\b Our\b consideration\bis\bthat\bfeatures\bthat\bdistinguish\bpositive\band\b negative\bopinion\bfor\bA1\band\bA2\bmay\bbe\bdifferent.\bIn\bother\b words,\b A1\b and\b A2\b might\b express\b and\b describe\b their\b appraisal\b in\b an\b individual\b way\b using\b their\b idiolects,\b so\b different\b from\b one\b another,\b that\b the\b overall\b polarity\b classification\b results\b might\b be\b improved,\b by\b classifying\b the\bdocuments\bwritten\bby\bA1\band\bA2\bseparately;\busing\bthe\b A1\band\bthe\bA2\bset\bof\bdocuments\bas\btwo\bdifferent\bdatasets\b for\bthe\bexperiment.\b \b The\baim\bof\bthe\bexperiment\bis\bto\bobserve\bthe\bhypothesis\b that\bin\bthe\bidiolects\bof\bthe\bdifferent\bauthors\btheir\bappraisal\b is\bexpressed\bin\ban\bindividual\bway.\bIn\border\bto\bprove\bthis,\b we\b constructed\b a\b corpus,\b in\b a\b similar\b format\b to\b the\b one\b described\b in\b (Pang,\b 2002).\b The\b corpus\b consisted\b of\b300\b short\b movie\b reviews,\b 30\b reviews\b for\b each\b of\b 10\b authors.\b For\b each\b of\b these\b 30,\b 15\b were\b positive\b and\b 15\b were\b negative\breviews.\bTo\binvestigate\bdifferent\bcorpus\bvolumes\b and\b to\b achieve\b higher\b statistically\b significant\b results,\b we\b doubled\b the\b corpus\b for\b each\b author,\b and\b repeated\b the\b experiment\b with\b 600\b documents,\b 30\b positive\b and\b 30\b negative\breviews\b for\beach\bauthor\bout\bof\b10.\bWe\b used\bthe\b unigram\b features\b with\b the\b Linear\b Support\b Vector\b \tachine1

\balgorithm\bfor\bthe\bpolarity\bclassification.\b \b As\b a\b baseline,\b we\b divided\b the\b corpus\b into\b 10\b groups,\b each\bhaving\b15\bpositive\band\b15\bnegative\b(30\bpositive\band\b 30\bnegative\bfor\bthe\bdoubled\bcorpus)\breviews,\bin\ba\brandom\b way,\b so\b that\b every\b group\b consisted\b of\b documents\b by\b different\b authors.\b We\b performed\b the\b 10-fold\b crossvalidation\bexperiment\bfor\beach\bof\bthese\bgroups\bseparately.\b The\b mean\b accuracy\b result\b for\b the\b baseline\b experiment\b with\b the\b 10\b shuffled\b groups\b was\b56.47%\b for\b the\b smaller\b corpus,\b64%\tfor\bthe\bdoubled\bcorpus.\b

sections.title: \b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\s\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b
paragraphs: 1 \bFor\bthe\bexperiments\bwe\bused\ba\bmachine\blearning\btool,\bWeka\b 3.6.1,\bthat\bis\bavailable\bfor\bdownload\bat\b http://www.cs.waikato.ac.nz/ml/weka/.\b\b \b For\bthe\bnext\bexperiment,\bwe\bused\bthe\bsame\breviews,\bbut\b we\b organized\b the\b 10\b groups\b of\b documents\b so\b that\b each\b group\bcorresponded\bto\ba\bsingle\bauthor,\bie.,\bit\bconsisted\bof\b 30\b positive\b and\b 30\b negative\b reviews\b by\b the\b same\b author.\b The\bauthors\bwere\bdifferent\bfor\bevery\bdifferent\bgroup.\bThe\b number\bof\bdocuments\band\bthe\bsettings\bof\bthe\bclassification\b experiment\bstayed\bthe\bsame.\bThe\bmean\baccuracy\bresult\bfor\b the\b 10\b groups\b was\b69.67%,\tfor\b the\b bigger\b corpus\b the\b mean\b value\b reached\b74.97%.\b The\b t-test\b showed\b that\b for\b the\bexperiment\bwith\b15\breviews\bwritten\bby\ba\bsingle\bauthor,\b the\bresult\bwas\bbetter\bthan\bfor\bthe\bone\bwith\b15\breviews\bby\b random\b authors,\b with\b 75%\b significance;\b whereas\b for\b30\b reviews\bby\ba\bsingle\bauthor\b yielded\bbetter\bresults\bthan\bfor\b 30\b reviews\b by\b different\b random\b authors\b with\b 89%\b significance.\b Using\b the\b entire\b corpus\b as\b a\b dataset\bfor\b the\b classification,\bfor\bthe\b300\breviews\bthe\baccuracy\bresult\bwas\b 73.17%,\b while\b for\b the\b 600\b reviews\b it\b was\b78.35%.\b We\b summarize\bthe\bresults\bin\bTable\b1.\b \b
\b Corpus\b1\b 300\btexts\b Corpus\b2\b 600\btexts\b Overall\b corpus\b classification\b 73.17\b 78.35\b 10\brandom\bgroups\b 56.47\b 64.00\b 10\bauthor\bgroups\b 69.67\b 74.97\b \b

Table\b1.\bThe\bpolarity\bclassification\bresults\bfor\bdifferent\bdatasets\b (%)\b The\b results\b for\b the\b both\b datasets\b confirmed\b our\b assumption\b that\b in\b different\b authors’\b idiolects\b the\b appraisal\b polarity\b is\b expressed\b in\b an\b individual\b way.\b \toreover,\bthe\bmean\bresult\bfor\bthe\b60\bdocuments\bby\bevery\b author\b was\b slightly\b better\b than\b the\b result\b for\b all\bthe\b 300\b documents.\bThis\bsuggest\bthe\bintuition\bthat\bin\bterms\bof\bthe\b volume\b of\b the\b datasets\b for\b polarity\b classification\bin\b the\b web,\b it\b is\b more\b useful\b to\b double\b the\b corpus\b by\b the\bsame\b single\b author,\b than\b to\b increase\b it\b 5\b fold\b using\b texts\b by\b different\bauthors.\b

sections.title: 3.2\t Getting\tto\tKnow\tthe\tAuthor:\tApp\bying\t Authorship\tAttribution\t
paragraphs: Knowing\bthe\bauthorship\bof\bthe\breviews,\b we\bcan\buse\bsuch\b information\b and\b increase\b the\b performance\b of\b polarity\b classification.\bHowever,\bthis\bis\bnot\ba\bvery\brealistic\bstate\bof\b affairs,\b when\b we\b use\b the\b ever-changing\b world\b wide\b web\b as\ba\bcorpus.\bA\bvery\bpopular\bway\bof\bhandling\bthis\bissue\bis\b automatic\b authorship\b attribution.\b In\b our\b next\b experiment\b we\b applied\b an\b authorship\b attribution\b algorithm\b to\b the\b existing\b document\b corpus,\b investigated\b if\b the\b resulting\b authorship\b information\b increases\b the\b performance\b of\b polarity\b classification;\b and\b observe\b the\b drawbacks\band\b limitations\bof\bthe\bapproach.\b \b We\b used\b the\b Java\b Graphical\b Authorship\b Attribution\b Program\b (JGAAP),\b described\b in\b (Juola,\b 2006),\b for\b supervised\bauthorship\battribution\btask.\bThe\btool\ballows\bfor\b the\bchoice\bof\bthe\bclassification\bfeatures,\bincluding\blexical,\b character,\bphonetic,\bgrammatical\bfeatures;\band\bthe\bchoice\b

of\b the\b classifying\b algorithm:\b the\b traditionally\b used\b Naïve\b Bayes\b and\b Support\b Vector\b \tachine\b and\b a\b number\b of\b others.\b For\b an\b authorship\b classification\b experiment\b using\b JGAAP\b it\b is\b necessary\b to\b have\b at\b least\b one\b training\b example\bper\beach\bauthor:\bit\bstarts\bwith\blearning\bauthorship\b classes\b from\b a\b trial\b set\b of\b documents\b by\b known\b authors,\b and\b proceeds\b to\b classifying\b every\b document\b with\b unknown\b authorship\b against\b the\b resulting\b authorship\b classes.\b \b In\b our\b corpus\b we\b had\b collected\b the\b 600\b documents\b by\b 10\b authors\b and\b a\b smaller\b 300-documents\b corpus,\b both\b balanced\bin\bterms\bof\bpolarity\band\bauthorship.\bTo\bperform\b authorship\b attribution,\b we\b used\b the\b smaller\b corpus\bas\b a\b reference\bgroup\bof\bdocuments\bwith\bknown\bauthorship:\bfor\b each\b author\b we\b had\b a\b learning\b set\b of\b 15\b positive\b and\b 15\b negative\bdocuments.\bWe\bused\bthe\brest,\bi.e.\bthe\bsecond\bhalf\b of\bthe\bbigger\bcorpus,\bas\ba\btest\bset.\b \b After\b testing\b a\b number\b of\b features,\b the\b Character\b Trigrams\b yielded\b the\b best\b result,\b confirming\b our\b expectation\b based\b on\b (Stamatatos,\b 2009).\b The\b Cosine\b distance\bwas\bexperimentally\bused\bas\bthe\bclassifier.\b \b The\b authorship\b classification\b accuracy\b results\b for\b different\b authors\b ranged\b very\b considerably\b from\b 0.3\b to\b 0.93,\b with\b the\b standard\b deviation\b of\b 0.26,\b and\b the\bmean\b accuracy\b rate\b among\b the\b 10\b authors\b reaching\b 0.64.\b We\b consider\bthis\ba\bsuccessful\bresult,\bbeing\bvery\bclose\bto\bsome\b of\bthe\bmean\baccuracy\bresults\breported\bin\b(Juola,\b2006)\bfor\b the\b “Ad-hoc\b Authorship\b Attribution\b Competition”\b (AAAC),\b namely\b 0.65.\b One\b the\b one\b hand,\b our\b reference\b group\b contained\b a\b very\b big\b number\b of\b documents\b comparing\b to\b the\b AAAC\b competition\b tasks,\b which\b made\b the\bclassification\btask\beasier.\bOn\banother\bhand,\bmost\bof\bthe\b tasks\b in\b the\b competition\b only\b included\b 3\b or\b less\b known\b author\bclasses,\bwhereas\bin\bour\bcase\btheir\bnumber\bwas\b10,\b which\b made\b the\b task\b harder\b and\b significantly\b decreased\b the\btask\bbaseline.\b \b The\b correlation\b coefficient\b for\b polarity\b classification\b and\b authorship\b attribution\b results\b for\b the\b 10\b authors\b reached\b a\b small\b but\b positive\b number\b of\b 0.176,\b indicating\b an\b insignificant\b trend\b that\b the\b style\b of\b the\b authors\b that\b is\b distinctive\b in\b terms\b of\b idiolect,\b it\b bears\b a\b lot\b of\b idiolect\b features\b that\b distinguish\b it\b from\b other\b author’s\b idiolects,\b allows\balso\bfor\beasier\bpolarity\bclassification.\b

sections.title: 3.3\t Po\barity\tC\bassification\tof\tAutomatica\b\by\t Attributed\tDocuments\t
paragraphs: We\b used\b the\b authorship\b attribution\b results\b described\b in\b section\b3.2\bin\border\bto\bmodify\bour\bcorpus.\bWe\bapplied\bthe\b results\bof\bthe\bclassification,\bso\bthat\bfor\bevery\bauthor\btheir\b document\b collection\b contained\b the\b documents,\b whose\b authorship\b was\b considered\b unknown\b and\b was\b identified\b automatically\b by\b the\b classifier.\b Thus,\b we\b got\b 20\b collections,\ba\bpositive\band\ba\bnegative\bone\bfor\beach\bauthor.\b Our\b goal\b was\b to\b proceed\b with\b the\b polarity\b classification\b experiment\b on\b the\b new,\b automatically\b attributed\b dataset,\b to\b find\b out\b if\b authorship\b attribution\b algorithms\b can\b aid\b sentiment\b analysis,\b the\b same\b way\b as\b knowing\b authorship\b did.\b \b According\bto\bour\bpresuppositions,\bthe\bapplication\bof\bthe\b authorship\b attribution\b algorithm\b raises\b real-life\b issues\b crucial\bfor\bthe\bpolarity\bclassification\btask.\b \b First\b of\b all,\b the\b resulting\b dataset\b was\b not\b balanced\b in\b terms\b of\b authors.\b With\b 30\b documents\b per\b author\b at\b the\b start,\b the\b resulting\b collections\b ranged\b from\b 8\b to\b 46\b texts.\b Secondly,\band\bmore\bimportantly,\bthe\bcollections\bwere\bnot\b balanced\bagainst\bpolarity\banymore\b(see\bTable\b2).\b\b \b \b Author\b id\b 1\b 2\b 3\b4\b 5\b 6\b 7\b 8\b9\b 10\b Positive\b\b20\b15\b1\b20\b15\b20\b15\b6\b11\b27\b Negative\b26\b6\b 7\b23\b14\b23\b12\b4\b14\b21\b \b

Table\b2.\bNumbers\bof\bfiles\bfor\beach\bof\bthe\ben\bauthors\bin\bthe\b authorship\battribution\bresults\b \b In\border\bto\bovercome\bthese\bissues,\bwe\bsupplemented\bthe\b resulting\b datasets\b with\b documents\b used\b as\b authorship\b attribution\blearning\bexamples,\bso\bthat\bfor\beach\bauthor:\b -the\b volumes\b of\b the\b positive\b and\b negative\b datasets\bwere\b the\bsame;\b -the\bvolume\bof\bthe\bset\bwas\bexactly\b30\bdocuments.\b For\bexample,\bfor\bthe\bsmallest\bset,\bconsisting\bof\b1\bnegative\b and\b 7\b positive\b reviews,\b we\b added\b 14\b randomly\b selected\b negative\b and\b 8\b positive\b reviews\b from\b the\b learning\b set\b of\b the\bsame\bauthor\bin\bthe\bauthorship\battribution\bexperiment.\b For\bthe\bbiggest\bset,\bcontaining\b27\bnegative\band\b21\bpositive\b files,\b we\b had\b to\b eliminate\b 12\b random\b negative\b and\b 6\b random\bpositive\bdocuments.\b \b Obviously,\b this\b modified\b the\b dataset\b considerably\band\b did\b not\b allow\b obtaining\b pure\b results,\b making\b the\b task\b easier\b for\b the\b smaller\b collections\b supplemented\b with\b documents\bby\bthe\bsame\bauthor,\band\bharder\bfor\bthe\bbigger\b collections,\b from\b which\bdocuments\b had\bto\bbe\beliminated.\b This\b imbalance\b is\b reflected\b in\b the\b big\b correlation\b coefficient\b value\b of\b -0.320\b between\b the\b polarity\b classification\b results\b and\b the\b authorship\b accuracy\bresults\b for\b each\b author:\b the\b collections\b attributed\b modestly\b were\b easier\bto\bclassify\bin\bterms\bof\bpolarity\bthan\bthe\bcollections\b attributed\b well,\b because\b the\b former\b were\b supplemented\b with\bfiles\bwith\bnative\bauthorship,\bwhereas\bfrom\bthe\blatter\b some\b files,\b most\b of\b the\b by\b the\b native\b author,\b were\b eliminated,\bin\border\bto\bbalance\bthe\bdataset.\b \b separate\b author-groups,\b with\b the\b correlation\b coefficient\b being\b 0.727.\b \b However,\b from\b Table\b 2\b it\b is\b obvious\b that\b not\b only\bfor\b different\b authors\b the\b sections.title: 4. Conc\busions\tand\tFurther\tWork\t
paragraphs: The\b experiment\b described\b in\b this\b paper\b confirmed\b the\b hypothesis\b that\b the\b appraisal\b polarity\b is\b expressed\b in\b an\b individual\b way\b by\b different\b authors;\b moreover,\b the\b differences\bare\bso\bconsiderable\bthat\bin\border\bto\binvestigate\b the\b polarity\b of\b documents\b automatically,\b a\b subsequent\b amount\b of\b documents\b by\b the\b same\b author\b gives\b more\b useful\b information\b than\b a\b much\b bigger\b sample\b of\b documents\bwritten\bby\bother\bauthors.\b \b The\bpersonalized\bapproach\bhas\bimproved\bthe\bresults\bof\b the\bpolarity\bclassification\btask.\bThis\bleads\bto\bthe\bintuition\b that\b any\b opinion\b mining\b task\b could\b be\b improved\b if\b considered\bin\bterms\bof\bidiolect.\bWe\bapplied\ban\bauthorship\b attribution\balgorithm,\bto\btest\bwhether,\band\bto\bwhat\bextent,\b the\b personalized\b approach\b with\b authors\b known\b could\bbe\b substituted\b with\b automatic\b authorship\b attribution.\bA\b simple\b authorship\b attribution\b algorithm\b with\b medium\b performance\b proved\b to\b supply\b useful\b information\b for\b polarity\b classification\b task,\b increasing\b the\b performance.\b As\b expected,\b authorship\b attribution\b imposed\b limitations\b on\bthe\bdataset\bin\bterms\bof\bits\bvolume\band\bbalance,\bmaking\b the\b subsequent\b polarity\b classification\b results\b harder\b to\b evaluate.\b \b Thus,\bwe\bconclude\bthat\btaking\binto\baccount\bauthorship,\b whether\b known\b or\b classified\b automatically,\b is\b a\b useful\b direction\b to\b take\b in\b sentiment\b analysis.\b However,\b the\b former\bis\bnot\bparticularly\brealistic\bprovided\bthat\bthe\bcorpus\b is\b extracted\b automatically\b from\b the\b web,\b and\b the\b latter\b imposes\b limitations,\b especially\b when\b applied\b to\b a\b small\b dataset.\bThis\bis\bwhy\bwe\bconsider\binvestigating\bfeatures\bof\b idiolect\b representing\b broader\b groups\b of\b authors\b in\bour\b future\b work,\b namely\b groups\b of\b authors\b sharing\b the\b same\b occupation.\b \b Our\b conjecture\b is\b that\b personal\b sense\b relates\b to\b occupation,\b or\b profession,\b in\b a\b particularly\b strong\b way.\b Occupation\b influences\b the\b everyday\b experience\b of\b a\b person,\b forming\b a\b sociolect,\b common\b among\b individuals\b of\b the\b same\b profession,\b but\b differentiating\b them\b from\b those\bworking\bin\banother\bfield.\bThus,\bthe\bnext\bstep\bof\bthe\b personal\bsense\band\bidiolect\bresearch\bis\bto\bfind\bout,\bin\bwhat\b way\band\bdegree\boccupation\bactually\bforms\ba\bsociolect\bin\ba\b person’s\blanguage\buse.\bOur\b hypothesis\bis\bthat\boccupation\b plays\ban\bimportant\brole\bin\bspeech,\band\bour\bgoal\bhere\bis\bto\b identify\b the\b features\b that\b reflect\b the\b professional\b differences\bin\blanguage\buse.\bThe\bexperiments\bare\baimed\bat\b harnessing\b differences\b in\b perspective\b for\b authors\b belonging\bto\bdifferent\bprofessions.\b \b To\b summarize,\b our\b initial\b results\b have\b proven\b that\b by\b acquiring\bknowledge\bof\bthe\bwriter's\bidiolect\bthe\bresults\bof\b the\b polarity\b classification\b task\b can\b be\b improved.\b In\b our\b future\b experiments,\b we\b will\b attempt\b to\b further\b reinforce\b the\bvalue\bof\bexploiting\bthe\bconcept\band\brole\bof\bidiolect\bin\b subjectivity\banalysis\btasks.\b
